verses.text: After we had torn ourselves away from them and set sail, we went in a straight course to Cos, and the next day to Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verses.comment: The journey from Miletus continues rapidly, following well-traveled sea routes of the ancient world.

verses.text: Finding a ship crossing over to Phoenicia, we went aboard and set sail.
verses.comment: Phoenicia (modern Lebanon) would have been a direct route east toward Jerusalem.

verses.text: When we had come in sight of Cyprus, leaving it on our left, we sailed on to Syria and landed at Tyre, for the ship was to unload its cargo there.
verses.comment: Tyre was a significant port in the ancient Mediterranean, already known in Christian circles.

verses.text: Having sought out the disciples, we stayed there seven days. They kept telling Paul, through the Spirit, not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: The Spirit's warnings here do not forbid Paul's journey, but prepare him and the church for coming trials.

verses.text: When our days there were over, we departed and continued on our journey, and they all, with wives and children, accompanied us until we were outside the city. Kneeling down on the beach, we prayed.
verses.comment: Note the public display of prayer, signifying the unity and family nature of the early Church.

verses.text: After saying farewell to one another, we boarded the ship, and they returned home.
verses.comment: Farewell scenes like this show the deep Christian bonds that exceed even natural ties.

verses.text: When we had finished the voyage from Tyre, we arrived at Ptolemais, and we greeted the brothers and stayed with them one day.
verses.comment: The greeting and hospitality among the faithful reflect the shared life of believers.

verses.text: On the next day we departed and came to Caesarea. We entered the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the Seven, and stayed with him.
verses.comment: Philip was one of the first appointed deacons (servants) in the Church and is seen here exercising hospitality.

verses.text: He had four unmarried daughters who prophesied.
verses.comment: This fulfills Joel's prophecy (Joel 2:28) about sons and daughters prophesying—a sign of the outpouring of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: While we stayed many days, a prophet named Agabus came down from Judea.
verses.comment: Agabus was already known as a true prophet; his appearance adds gravity to the warning to Paul.

verses.text: Coming to us, he took Paul’s belt, bound his own feet and hands, and said, 'This is what the Holy Spirit says: In this way the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man who owns this belt and will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.'
verses.comment: Prophetic sign-acts, like those in the Old Testament, show continuity between old and new covenants in revelation.

verses.text: When we heard this, both we and the local people urged him not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Pressure from Christian companions highlights Paul’s resolve to obey God’s will above human fears.

verses.text: Then Paul answered, 'What are you doing, weeping and breaking my heart? For I am ready not only to be bound, but even to die at Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus.'
verses.comment: Paul’s willing self-offering echoes Christ’s own obedience and is a model of united suffering with Christ (Romans 8:17).

verses.text: When he would not be persuaded, we stopped and said, 'Let the will of the Lord be done.'
verses.comment: This echoes Jesus’ own words in Gethsemane (Luke 22:42)—submitting to God’s will in trial.

verses.text: After those days we got ready and went up to Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Going ‘up’ to Jerusalem reflects its spiritual as well as its literal elevation.

verses.text: Some of the disciples from Caesarea went with us, bringing us to the house of Mnason of Cyprus, an early disciple, with whom we should stay.
verses.comment: ‘Early disciple’ shows the continuity of the faith from the Church’s earliest days.

verses.text: When we had come to Jerusalem, the brothers received us gladly.
verses.comment: Fellowship and joyful welcome reinforce the unity of the universal Church.

verses.text: The next day Paul went in with us to James, and all the elders were present.
verses.comment: James’ role as leader of the Jerusalem Church and the elders present show the apostolic and episcopal structure from the beginning.

verses.text: After greeting them, Paul reported one by one the things God had done among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verses.comment: Paul is accountable to the leadership. Sharing missionary fruits affirms apostolic authority over doctrine and practice.

verses.text: When they heard it, they glorified God. They said to him, 'You see, brother, how many thousands of Jews there are who have believed, and all of them are zealous for the law.'
verses.comment: The early church included many Jews still zealous for the Law, showing the Church’s deep roots in God’s ancient people.

verses.text: They have been informed about you, that you teach all the Jews who are among the Gentiles to forsake Moses, telling them not to circumcise their children or walk according to our customs.
verses.comment: Paul did not teach apostasy from the Law but its fulfillment in Christ. These rumors reflect tensions regarding Law and Gospel in the early community.

verses.text: What is to be done? They will certainly hear that you have come.
verses.comment: The leaders anticipate conflict and wisely seek a solution to preserve unity.

verses.text: Do therefore what we tell you. We have four men who are under a vow.
verses.comment: These vows are likely Nazarite vows from the Law, which included temporary separation and ritual practices.

verses.text: Take these men and purify yourself with them and pay their expenses, so that they may shave their heads. Then all will know there is nothing in the things they have been told about you, but that you yourself live in observance of the law.
verses.comment: Paul’s humility in joining ritual purification upholds the unity of the Church and love for the brethren.

verses.text: But about the Gentiles who have believed, we sent a letter, with our judgment, that they should abstain from what has been sacrificed to idols, from blood, from what is strangled, and from sexual immorality.
verses.comment: This repeats the decrees of the Jerusalem Council, showing the Church’s authority to bind consciences on moral matters.

verses.text: Then Paul took the men, and the next day he purified himself along with them and went into the temple, giving notice when the days of purification would be fulfilled and the offering presented for each one of them.
verses.comment: Paul, like Christ, fulfills the law (see Matthew 5:17) and maintains fellowship with all believers.

verses.text: When the seven days were almost completed, the Jews from Asia, seeing him in the temple, stirred up the whole crowd and laid hands on him,
verses.comment: Hostility against Paul comes from those refusing to accept fulfillment of the Old Covenant in Christ.

verses.text: crying out, 'Men of Israel, help! This is the man who teaches everyone everywhere against the people and the law and this place. Moreover, he even brought Greeks into the temple and has defiled this holy place.'
verses.comment: The false accusation mirrors charges brought against Stephen (Acts 6:13-14) and ultimately Christ Himself.

verses.text: (For they had previously seen Trophimus the Ephesian with him in the city, and they supposed Paul had brought him into the temple.)
verses.comment: Gentiles were forbidden from the inner courts of the temple. The assumption, not fact, provoked outrage.

verses.text: All the city was stirred up, and people ran together. They seized Paul and dragged him out of the temple, and immediately the gates were shut.
verses.comment: The crowd’s violence echoes mob scenes in the Gospels, especially the Passion narratives.

verses.text: While they were seeking to kill him, word came to the tribune of the cohort that all Jerusalem was in confusion.
verses.comment: Roman oversight of Jerusalem is evident—civil authority reacts quickly to preserve order.

verses.text: At once he took soldiers and centurions and ran down to them. When they saw the tribune and the soldiers, they stopped beating Paul.
verses.comment: Paul’s rescue by Romans foreshadows the international mission of the Church. God preserves His messengers.

verses.text: Then the tribune came up and arrested him and ordered him to be bound with two chains. He inquired who he was and what he had done.
verses.comment: Paul’s binding, foretold by Agabus, mirrors Christ’s own arrest and chains—suffering as a servant.

verses.text: Some in the crowd were shouting one thing, some another, and as he could not learn the facts because of the uproar, he ordered Paul to be brought into the barracks.
verses.comment: Confusion and mob justice contrast with the order and discernment the Church is called to embody.

verses.text: When he came to the steps, he was actually carried by the soldiers because of the violence of the crowd,
verses.comment: This dramatic scene underscores the hostility the Gospel provokes in the world.

verses.text: for the mob of the people followed, crying out, 'Away with him!'
verses.comment: The cry 'Away with him!' mirrors the crowd’s call for Jesus’ crucifixion—Paul shares in Christ’s sufferings.

verses.text: As Paul was about to be brought into the barracks, he said to the tribune, 'May I say something to you?' And he replied, 'Do you know Greek?'
verses.comment: Paul’s knowledge of languages and education enabled him to boldly witness to all kinds of people.

verses.text: 'Are you not the Egyptian, then, who recently stirred up a revolt and led the four thousand men of the Assassins out into the wilderness?'
verses.comment: Roman officials struggled to distinguish various movements. Christianity was often misunderstood as a political threat.

verses.text: Paul replied, 'I am a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of no insignificant city. I beg you, let me speak to the people.'
verses.comment: Paul’s respectful appeal shows commitment not only to civil order but also to witness for Christ with wisdom.

verses.text: When he had given him permission, Paul, standing on the steps, motioned with his hand to the people. When there was a great silence, he addressed them in the Hebrew language:
verses.comment: Paul will give his testimony in the next chapter. Speaking in Hebrew shows Paul’s respect for Israel’s heritage and his desire to build unity between Jew and Gentile in one faith.
